Write in dark blue or black pen. You may use a pencil for any diagrams or graphs. Do not use staples, paper clips, highlighters, glue or correction fluid. DO NOT WRITE IN ANY BARCODES. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 501, 253, 516]]<|/det|> Answer all questions. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 527, 758, 558]]<|/det|> At the end of the examination, fasten all your work securely together. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 73, 96, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 73, 808, 92]]<|/det|>
An IGCSE student is determining the mass of a metre rule using a balancing method

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 104, 363, 122]]<|/det|>
Fig. 1.1 shows the apparatus.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[210, 146, 739, 240]]<|/det|>
<center>Fig. 1.1 </center>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 291, 846, 308]]<|/det|>
Mass **M** is placed on the rule. The position of the pivot is adjusted until the rule balances.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 322, 146, 341]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 322, 875, 355]]<|/det|>
The student chooses a mass **M** which is similar to the mass of the metre rule. Suggest a suitable value for the mass.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[450, 384, 875, 402]]<|/det|>
<form>suitable mass = ............................................................ [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 415, 148, 434]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 415, 875, 433]]<|/det|>
The mass is cylindrical and has a diameter slightly larger than the width of the metre rule.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 447, 875, 495]]<|/det|>
Describe briefly how you would place the mass so that its centre of mass is exactly over the 90.0 cm mark on the metre rule. You should draw a diagram and mark the position of the centre of mass on the cylinder.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[850, 707, 876, 727]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 739, 146, 757]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 739, 875, 772]]<|/det|>
From your experience of carrying out balancing experiments of this type, suggest one difficulty that you are likely to come across that could make the final result inaccurate.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[850, 847, 876, 865]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 73, 148, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 816, 107]]<|/det|>
The student takes a reading of \(x\) and the corresponding reading of \(y\). He then calculates the mass of the metre rule.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 120, 880, 153]]<|/det|>
Suggest how you would improve the reliability of the value of the mass of the metre rule, using this method.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[846, 197, 875, 215]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 228, 146, 246]]<|/det|>
<label>(e)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 228, 875, 260]]<|/det|>
Another student carries out a similar experiment to determine the mass of a \(50 \text{cm}\) metal strip. She calculates the mass and writes down "mass = \(234.872 \text{g}\)".

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 274, 875, 306]]<|/det|>
She checks the mass on an accurate balance. The value is \(235 \text{g}\). She thinks she must have made a mistake in her experiment.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 320, 695, 338]]<|/det|>
Write a brief comment on the accuracy of her experimental result.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[799, 444, 875, 463]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 6]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 73, 96, 92]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 677, 92]]<|/det|> The IGCSE class is investigating the heating of a thermometer bulb. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 104, 524, 122]]<|/det|> The apparatus is shown in Figs. 2.1, 2.2 and 2.3. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 134, 808, 266]]<|/det|> <|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[443, 287, 509, 305]]<|/det|> 
Fig. 2.1

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 319, 148, 337]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 319, 728, 337]]<|/det|>
Record the value of room temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{R}}\) shown on the thermometer.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 350, 808, 383]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 400, 560, 420]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 463, 148, 481]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 463, 875, 558]]<|/det|>
A student switches on the lamp and places the thermometer so that its bulb is a horizontal distance \(d = 100 \text{mm}\) from the surface of the lamp, as shown in Fig. 2.1. She records the distance \(d\) between the thermometer bulb and the surface of the lamp. She also records the temperature \(\theta\) shown on the thermometer. She repeats the procedure using values of \(d\) of \(80 \text{mm}\), \(60 \text{mm}\), \(40 \text{mm}\), \(20 \text{mm}\) and \(10 \text{mm}\). The temperature readings are shown in Table 2.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 572, 183, 590]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 572, 463, 588]]<|/det|>
Record the \(d\) values in the table.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 597, 180, 615]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 597, 553, 613]]<|/det|>
Complete the column headings in the table.

<|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[339, 664, 617, 904]]<|/det|>

\(d/\)\(\theta /\)
52
56
61
67
75
86


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[848, 904, 876, 922]]<|/det|>
[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 73, 146, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 73, 850, 121]]<|/det|>
The student moves the thermometer away from the lamp and waits for about a second for the thermometer to cool. She places the thermometer so that its bulb is a very close distance \(d_{\mathrm{v}} = 100 \mathrm{mm}\) from the top surface of the lamp, as shown in Fig. 2.3.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[260, 134, 692, 280]]<|/det|>
<center>Fig. 2.3 </center>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 326, 744, 344]]<|/det|>
She records the temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{v}}\) shown on the thermometer: \(\theta_{\mathrm{v}} = 55^{\circ}\mathrm{C}.\) 

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 357, 873, 390]]<|/det|>
Calculate the difference between \(\theta_{\mathrm{v}}\) and the thermometer reading \(\theta_{\mathrm{H}}\) at a horizontal distance of \(100\mathrm{mm}\) from the lamp. State whether \(\theta_{\mathrm{v}}\) is higher, lower or the same as \(\theta_{\mathrm{H}}\).

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[378, 408, 870, 440]]<|/det|>
\[\text{temperature difference} = \text{....................................................................}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[544, 465, 873, 483]]<|/det|>
<form>\(\theta_{\mathrm{v}}\) is .................................................................... [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 497, 148, 515]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 497, 873, 545]]<|/det|>
A student suggests that \(\theta_{\mathrm{v}}\) will be higher than the thermometer reading \(\theta_{\mathrm{H}}\) because thermal energy will travel by infra-red radiation and convection to the thermometer bulb above the lamp but by infra-red radiation only when the bulb is to one side of the lamp.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 559, 873, 606]]<|/det|>
If the experiment were to be repeated in order to investigate this suggestion it would be important to control the conditions. Suggest two such conditions, relevant to this investigation, that should be controlled.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 621, 870, 638]]<|/det|>
1. ....................................................................................................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 653, 870, 670]]<|/det|>
2. ....................................................................................................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[848, 670, 875, 687]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 700, 146, 717]]<|/det|>
<label>(e)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 700, 873, 732]]<|/det|>
Briefly describe a precaution that you would take in this experiment in order to obtain a reliable result.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[799, 834, 875, 852]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 73, 94, 92]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 744, 92]]<|/det|> The IGCSE class is determining the resistance of a fixed resistor in a circuit. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 104, 374, 122]]<|/det|> The circuit is shown in Fig. 3.1. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[232, 135, 718, 298]]<|/det|> <|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[443, 318, 510, 335]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 349, 875, 396]]<|/det|>
A student places the sliding contact on the resistance wire at a distance \(d = 10.0 \text{cm}\) from point \(\mathbf{A}\). He measures the current \(I\) in the circuit and the p.d. \(V\) across the resistor \(\mathbf{R}\). He repeats the procedure using \(d\) values of \(30.0 \text{cm}\), \(50.0 \text{cm}\), \(70.0 \text{cm}\) and \(90.0 \text{cm}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 411, 462, 428]]<|/det|>
The readings are shown in Table 3.1.

V/VI/A

30.01.30.87
50.01.00.67
70.00.80.53
90.00.70.47

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 73, 808, 107]]<|/det|>
Plot a graph of \(V / V\) (\(y\)-axis) against \(I / A\) (\(x\)-axis). You do not need to include origin (0, 0) on your graph.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 594, 92]]<|/det|>

<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 320, 875, 370]]<|/det|>
A student places the lens between the object and the screen and close to the object. She moves the lens towards the screen until a clearly focused, enlarged image is formed on the screen.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 382, 180, 400]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 382, 875, 400]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[555, 412, 870, 430]]<|/det|>
\[d = \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \quad (2)\]

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[555, 505, 870, 523]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 737, 875, 784]]<|/det|>
Without moving the illuminated object or the screen, the student moves the lens towards the screen until a clearly focused, **diminished** image is formed on the screen. She measures the distance \(Y\) between the centre of the lens and the screen: \(Y = 19.0 \text{cm}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 797, 693, 821]]<|/det|>
Calculate the focal length \(f\) of the lens using the equation \(f = \frac{XY}{D}\) .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 144, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 73, 816, 107]]<|/det|>
The student turns the lens through an angle of \(180^{\circ}\) and repeats the procedure above a value for the focal length \(f = 14.7 \text{cm}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 120, 875, 170]]<|/det|>
Theory suggests that the two values of the focal length \(f\) should be the same. State whether the results support this theory and justify your answer by reference to the results.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 73, 816, 107]]<|/det|>

Calculate the volume \(V_{\mathrm{A}}\) of air in the test-tube using the equation \(V_{\mathrm{A}} = (V_{3} - V_{1}) - V_{\mathrm{G}}.\)

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[544, 788, 870, 808]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[846, 804, 875, 823]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 73, 148, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 73, 850, 120]]<|/det|>
The student removes the test-tube from the measuring cylinder and fills the test-tube with water from a beaker. He pours the water from the test-tube into an empty measuring cylinder and records the volume \(V_{\mathrm{W}}\) of water:

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[541, 131, 720, 155]]<|/det|>
\[V_{\mathrm{W}} = \text{...} 18 \text{cm}^3\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 165, 873, 199]]<|/det|>
The student has attempted to determine the internal volume of the test-tube by two methods. His two values for the internal volume are \(V_{\mathrm{A}}\) and \(V_{\mathrm{W}}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 211, 873, 260]]<|/det|>
